newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court says French law discriminates against women.
newsitem.headline: Court says French law discriminates against women.

text.p: France must allow women to work night shifts, the European Court of Justice said on Thursday.
The court ruled that EU law clearly guaranteed women the same access to employment as men and the French ban on allowing women to work at night was discriminatory.

Restrictions on nightwork could amount to a ban on the freedom to work at all, and certainly restricted women from access to higher wages paid at night, European Commission spokeswoman Barbara Nolan said.

France and Italy were the last two remaining member states which had not enacted legislation permitting women to work at night. "The Commission is very pleased the court agreed with our position," Nolan said.

The French employment code prohibits nightwork for women in plants, factories and workshops of any kind whatsoever, but provides an exception for women in upper level managerial and technical positions and where serious circumstances of national interest are at stake.
It was originally enacted on the basis of standards set by the International Labour Organization in 1948.

The French government denies there is any discrimination between men and women who wish to work at night. French lawyers argued Frenchwomen could rely directly on the EU law before French courts and were therefore fully protected.
But the court agreed with the European Commission that France should have repealed the nightwork provision and replaced it with a law guaranteeing women the right to work at night.
